contentrichtext.text: {{infobox UK place | country = England | latitude = 52.5167 | longitude = 0.2333 | os_grid_reference = TL526940 | official_name = Welney | population = 528 | area_total_km2 = 20.73 | static_image = | static_image_caption = | shire_district = [[King's Lynn and West Norfolk]] | shire_county = [[Norfolk]] | region = East of England | civil_parish = Welney | constituency_westminster = | postcode_district = PE14 | postcode_area = PE | post_town = WISBECH | dial_code = 01354 | london_distance = |static_image = [[File:St Mary's Church and water tower - geograph.org.uk - 432107.jpg|240px]] |static_image_caption= <small>St Mary's Church, Welney</small> }} '''Welney''' is a [[village]] and [[civil parishes in England|civil parish]] in [[the Fens]] of [[England]], and the [[county]] of [[Norfolk]]. The village is situated immediately to the west of parallel [[Old Bedford River]], [[River Delph]] and [[New Bedford River]], which are here crossed by the [[A1101 road]]. The village is some {{convert|15|km|abbr=on}} south-west of the town of [[Downham Market]], {{convert|30|km|abbr=on}} south of the town of [[King's Lynn]] and {{convert|70|km|abbr=on}} west of the city of [[Norwich]]. The county boundary with [[Cambridgeshire]] is adjacent, and the city of [[Cambridge]] lies {{convert|40|km|abbr=on}} to the south.<ref>Ordnance Survey (1999). ''OS Explorer Map 228 - March & Ely''. ISBN 0-319-21860-0.</ref> It covers an area of {{convert|20.73|km2|abbr=on}} and had a population of 528 in 217 households as of the [[United Kingdom Census 2001|2001 census]].<ref>[http://www.norfolk.gov.uk/consumption/groups/public/documents/general_resources/ncc017867.xls Census population and household counts for unparished urban areas and all parishes]. Office for National Statistics & Norfolk County Council (2001). Retrieved 20 June 2009.</ref> For the purposes of local government, it falls within the [[Non-metropolitan district|district]] of [[King's Lynn and West Norfolk]]. In the 14th century, Welney was called ''Wellenhe'', meaning "a river called Welle" (the old name of the [[Old Croft River]]). In the second half of the 19th century, Welney became famous for its [[Fen skating|skaters]]. Welney is situated on the [[Ouse Washes]], an internationally important area of [[wildlife]] [[Conservation movement|conservation]]. [[WWT Welney]] is a [[nature reserve]] in the care of the [[Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust]]. Nearby, there are also the [[RSPB Ouse Washes]], a reserve managed by the [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]]. ==Listen to Welney== *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/factual/opencountry.shtml BBC Radio 4 nature programme from Welney] ==The Church== The Church in Welney is called St Mary's Church which is named after the Virgin Mary. ==The Cricket Club== The Welney Croft Cricket Club (WCCC)has been a centre of attention and social gathering for over 50 years for the locals to the village. The season begins in mid May and finishes in late September. It has a lovely ground and is one of the best maintained grounds for a village in the country. == Notes == {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Welney}} {{oscoor gbx|TL526940}}. *[http://www.origins.org.uk/genuki/NFK/places/w/welney/ Information from Genuki Norfolk] on Welney. *[http://www.welney.org.uk/ Welney's website] {{Civil Parishes of King's Lynn and West Norfolk}} [[Category:Villages in Norfolk]] [[Category:King's Lynn and West Norfolk]] [[Category:Civil parishes in Norfolk]]
